title: To everyone who complains about the ADC circlejerk
body:
Look, I know that seeing endless posts about ADCs isn't the most fun thing in the world. But to all those who simply dismiss all those posts as "whining" or "circlejerk" or "salt", no. ADCs ARE a problem right now. They have been a problem in the past, and they will probably also be a problem in the future.

Don't get me wrong, I love a good salty rant once in a while, but not 24/7. However, I also don't like people flat out dismissing the concerns of a clearly very large number of players. If there are hundreds, thousands even of players saying that ADCs are too strong, then perhaps they are.

P.S: they are

replies.body: When a circlejerk gets so strong that there's an anticirclejerk circlejerk, you know there's a problem and people don't offer solutions.

While I agree that a lot of threads criticizing marksman balance/design essentially say the same thing, and unfortunately often don't dig deep enough into how to address the problem, I also think it's understandable for there to be a degree of repetition, because this is an ongoing issue that has so far received no Riot response, so to anyone posting those kinds of threads or comments it doesn't feel like they're being listened to. Ideally, the best solution would be to concentrate hot-button issues onto single, high-visibility threads, so that the same discussion wouldn't take up most of the front page, but we've had technical problems trying to implement that in the past.

I'm with you here, it's tiresome to see the same thing get said over and over again, and I think there needs to be a means of culling repetition across the front page of Gameplay, where there are many topics that deserved to be discussed and precious little space. What are your thoughts on answering this? Do you think hosting a pinned megathread on a particularly high-visibility topic could help Gameplay?

Dig deep enough? There's been years worth of complaints pointing out a handful of issues. Some of the problems are direct design flaws, others incidental oversights, and occasionally ignorant co-operation between the different branches; but usually a combination. 
So let me elaborate for you.

Marksmen get too much damage too fast for any other class to meaningfully compete unless some cheesy strategy is used; critical hits specifically turning them from dps threats to physical bursters, often hitting quadruple digits on a single auto-attack once they get fed. 
Reduce their damage output in some fashion, whether slowing their power curve or curbing their overall power. Rework critical hits, or lower damage or attack speed on their items. Or significantly increase the costs of their items, since they already have some of the easiest time farming.

Lifesteal is disgustingly prevalent, applying both on critical hits and repeatedly from boosted attack speed, generally prevents them from being killed by other dps dangers; and practically requiring stun-locking or even more burst to kill them. 
Lower lifesteal or remove it's boosted interaction with critical hits, or make it an overtime effect similar to the bleed on death's dance. 

Safety nets! I remember back in season one through five when they had to be protected by their teammates in a fight. Thanks to tacked on effects to their already powerful primary and niche items, they get increased windows of power via extra damage reduction and delay, ontop of guardian's angel being reworked to benefit them. A few niche items like essance reaver and runaan's hurricane should've stayed on the sidelines, as they can give way too much influence over the game depending on the marksmen. That's not counting the extra movement speed on a handful of items, or several activatable items to give them even more of an edge against any competition. 
Undo the excessive buffs from the items in pre-season six (as I doubt they've kept previous states of the reworked champions), this alone should be enough to pull them back into line with the other classes. Either remove the bonus movement speed, the free damage reduction/delay, or the extra  effects on their counter items. Things like maw of malmortius and phantom dancer did their job well enough before getting buffed; while other spiteful designs like dominik's regards and guardian angel, are just double standards, allowing one class to screw over another for doing it's job.

If an item is good, marksmen will eventually abuse it, then riot guts the item instead of their interaction with it. It noticeably started in season two with ezreal, and it's become a more obnoxious as time has gone on. Ask juggernauts about sterak's gage, or tanks about dead man's plate, or assassins about edge of night. 
Drop the favoritism; make items melee only, or change them to rely on bonus stats so it benefits intended classes significantly more.

If you read through my post history, you'll see that I'm personally well aware of the various threads that got made about marksmen, and share many of the opinions you posted here. :P

I'm not saying that the conversation about marksmen doesn't dig deep enough in general, but as often happens when a topic trends on Gameplay, many threads often copy other threads on the front page without adding much to the conversation, and sometimes just try to cash in on the sentiment with a catchy title and too little substance. In recent times, one of the topics _du jour_ has been marksman balance, and while many valuable things have been said about marksmen on the Boards, many threads unfortunately missed that opportunity while still bringing up the subject.

I agree that there's years worth of complaints around marksmen that have yet to be resolved, and I definitely want to see those issues get discussed more and, with enough luck, answered by Riot. One of the current issues with Gameplay, though, is that often there's a pretty big noise-to-signal ratio that makes discussion difficult, largely because of those less contributive threads. There is plenty of useful conversation to have around marksmen, but in order for that conversation to have more of an impact we all need to collectively step up our game, and avoid simply jumping on the bandwagon for easy upvotes.

I tend not to unless I've had several conversations with someone, I already burn too much time going down similar rabbit holes, lol. Nice to hear from fellow intellectual though!

The copy&paste posts is probably due to these problems being significantly reoccurring, repeatedly aggravating parts of the community; which can point out a design problem, whether a philosophy or logistical, still one that shouldn't have left the drawing board as is. 

Marksmen weren't as much of a problem years ago, many longtime players agree season three and five were some of the best balance wise. However marksmen have had the biggest trend of being buffed out of any class, thus stirring up hatred for them. 

Sadly I concur any meaningful discussion is problematic to reach the right people. Doesn't help riot outright ignores their own forums in favor of other media. 
Unfortunately I don't see more sophisticated discussions becoming prominent as long as esports is the focus of the company; as it's drawn in much younger folk who lack more detailed and critical thinking, along with sports fan style players who merely mimic other more popular players and defend them regardless of evidence.

Your post is quite readable, and thank you for the suggestion! Ideally, the idea of a category that would appear while relevant, and disappear while not, would be what we'd want to achieve with megathreads, but currently we're doing this with pretty much the same resources as an average poster, give or take the ability to pin threads (which also auto-removes pinned threads from the front page, so it can potentially harm visibility). We're still experimenting on the format (we did a Rengar megathread a little while back, which had mixed results), and one of the important factors for a megathread should definitely be relevance.

Technically he's right, though. Adc means "Attack damage carry", which actually translates to any carry type champion with physical damage. This includes most marksmen, juggernauts and skirmishers. On the other hand, it's common use to associate adc with marksmen, and to call its position in bot lane as adc, since the subclass system is a relatively recent one, and people are used to marksmen being the "only" carry thanks to old features that were unique to them.
On another hand, though, there is also a marksman that  is not an adc, and it's Corki after the marksmen rework.

Corki is still an attack damage carry. He still mostly builds AD, he just deals magic damage. But Attack Damage Carry has nothing to do with physical as a damage type, it's just AD as a stat.

The problem lies in the origin of the term. Why have the terms adc and apc even been born? Why not call them simply carry? If those characteristics were fused in the name it means they had some important meaning. Why should I care if a carry is ad or ap? Having to distinguish between ad and ap is important because it changes the stat I have to buy to counter him. If it's an adc, I buy armor. If it's an apc, I buy mr. So why did they use the stats attack damage and ability power and not directly physical and magic damage? Well, because, at the time, physical dealers built ad, and magic dealers built ap. There was an association between the two because it was all there was.
It was clearly a faulty way, since no one at Riot ever relegated ad to physical and ap to magic. They are simply stats used to balance the game. Like for example Lee Sin's E that scales ad but deals magic damage.
The problem is that now we have a carry that scales ad but actually deals magic damage, Corki. How should we call him? He scales ad, so adc? But the core meaning of adc is that "he deals physical damage, so I build armor", and here's the problem. So, at the end, it's probably more correct call him an apc since, even if he doesn't build ap, he deals magic damage which is what apc means.
In the same way, if someday Riot decides to create a "true" physical damage battle mage that scales ap but deals physical damage (so he doesn't double down on auto attacks) he should probably be called adc, because you will still use armor to counter him.

Now my objective isn't to poke fun at you, but rather to show you that just because a role has always existed and been important doesn't mean that the meta has always revolved around that role.

Support is a role, not a class. Metas are defined by the classes which are strong within them, not the roles which are strong. We've had assassin metas, tank metas, etc... because assassins and tanks are classes not roles. 

Meanwhile we've had mage supports, enchanter supports, warden supports, etc... just like we've had tank tops, fighter tops, carry tops, ... just like we've had mage mids, adc mids, assassin mids, ... 

But bot lane has been marksmen since season 1. We get variance on the other roles, with multiple classes having metas that favor them in that role or not.
It's not that ADCs are always meta, it's that they're never really out of meta. They're never a bad pick, and that's a sign of them being too strong.

False. There are a lot of subclasses that deal high dps endgame. These are marksmen, juggernauts, skirmishers and battle mages. Every champion belonging to one of these subclasses is a late game carry.
You can try on a dummy, if you want. Champions not-marksmen from one the subclasses listed will deal dps comparable to that of a traditional marksman.
The difference obviously lies in the fact that we don't fight dummies. This means that dps is not everything and there are other things.
Things like range, that juggernauts and skirmishers lack. Sustain, that battle mages lack. Mobility, that juggernauts and battle mages lack. Tank shredding and objective taking, that juggernauts mostly lack. Reliability in dealing damage: battle mages and juggernauts mostly have gimmicks attached to it or it's skillshot based, and there are only a couple of straight up autoattacking skirmishers (Yi, Tryn and Yasuo). The only thing marksmen really lack is tankiness, but with the current builds this is also arguable.
So no, dps is not the reason marksmen are always picked.
No, marksmen are the only class who can sufficiently build full damage and utilize DPS.

I said, try it on a dummy. Take Master Yi and build him full crit/as and he will probably have even more dps than marksmen. Take Darius, build him like a juggernaut, and you'll see he will have similar dps to a marksman. Take any juggernaut, skirmisher or battle mage, build them with their optimal build and try them on a dummy. They will still deal comparable dps to a marksman.
What makes marksmen special is range, reliability and sustain, not dps.
